author: Dan Sokil
title: Lifetime at the library: Towns honor retiring North Wales Area Library director Jayne Blackledge
text: NORTH WALES ‚Äî A local fixture will soon be stepping down, and local officials are celebrating her decades of devotion to the community. North Wales and Upper Gwynedd have both recognized Jayne Blackledge, longtime director of the North Wales Area Library , as she nears the end of a distinguished career. ‚ÄúLater this week, we‚Äôll be celebrating Jayne Blackledge‚Äôs retirement from the North Wales Area Library. I‚Äôm excited to join that celebration, and I will be proclaiming March 15 as ‚ÄòJayne Blackledge Day‚Äô in North Wales,‚Äù said borough Mayor Neil McDevitt. As leader of the library since the late 1990s, Blackledge has seen the library move in 2009 ‚Äì 10 from a spot inside North Wales Elementary School to a renovated former factory on Swartley Street ‚Äî supervising subsequent fixes and upgrades in and around the building ‚Äî and led through the turbulent COVID era when libraries shuttered their doors and shifted to online and drive-up offerings . She‚Äôs also overseen countless new library programs and innovations, including free classic books for newborns , new online offerings including daily story time book readings on the library‚Äôs Facebook page , courses in sign language , book drives in memory of school shooting victims , free museum passes to local destinations , a ‚ÄòStar Library‚Äô designation as one of the best in the state , and a ‚ÄòHuman Library‚Äô program where visitors can learn from the life stories of others. ‚ÄúAnyone who has visited the library, or ever heard of our library, will know Jayne has been a very huge part of our success,‚Äù said borough Manager Christine Hart. A retirement gala in her honor will be held Friday, March 15, from 6 p.m. to 10 p.m. at the William Penn Inn in Lower Gwynedd; tickets to the gala are available online or in person at the library. In addition to the Mayoral proclamation from North Wales, the board of commissioners in Upper Gwynedd recognized Blackledge this week , as commissioners President Katherine Carter read a formal recognition proclamation saying the township was ‚Äúforever grateful‚Äù for Blackledge‚Äôs 43 years of dedication. ‚ÄúThe library offers something for everyone, and that is thanks to Jayne‚Äôs dynamic leadership,‚Äù she said. Commissioner Greg Moll said he fondly recalled taking his two children there often as they grew up, calling it ‚Äúa magical experience.‚Äù ‚ÄúI can remember my son dressed as a turtle, complete with shell backpack, to go take pictures at the library, and pull out books and read them. For a parent, when we first started going to the library, what a great resource for our community. So thank you to Jayne for everything that she‚Äôs done, for the library and for our community, and all the children and all the adults that benefit as a result,‚Äù he said. Carter recalled when her daughter, now in her 30s, first filled out a library card application with Blackledge 20-some years ago, ‚Äúand recently she called, and Jayne renewed her library card for her.‚Äù ‚ÄúI said to her the other day, I said ‚ÄòShe‚Äôs retiring,‚Äô and she‚Äôs like, ‚ÄòWhat‚Äôs going to happen to the library?‚Äô It‚Äôll still be there. So just in small ways, you‚Äôve affected my family, and we appreciate everything,‚Äù Carter said. ‚ÄúMy grandchildren loved coming there for the human library ‚Äî they didn‚Äôt understand when I said it, they were like, ‚ÄòReally? Humans?‚Äô But they really enjoyed it, and I know my neighbor‚Äôs four kids really enjoy the library, so we appreciate it, and thank you so much for your years of service,‚Äù she said. And former commissioner Martha Simelaro said she thought Blackledge had been the perfect library director: a devoted and welcoming gatekeeper of learning, and leader to uncharted literary territory. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre also the stewards of curiosity. They ensure that every seeker finds their direction, not only to facts, but also to wonder,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre also storytellers, and Jayne‚Äôs a good one, not just from books but from their own experiences. And then these stories become a part of the library‚Äôs lore.‚Äù ‚ÄúThese are just a few of the things that librarians do, and this is what Jayne has done so well, every day for over 40 years. So tonight we honor Jayne, who lights up our minds and our hearts, and shaped many of our literary journeys. Thank you for making our world richer, one book at a time. We‚Äôll miss you.‚Äù As she accepted the proclamation, Blackledge thanked the entire community for their support, and said she‚Äôs been ‚Äúreally lucky to spend an entire lifetime‚Äù there, including while her mother was the previous library director. ‚ÄúI was raised in the North Wales library. When I was a little girl, I went there‚Ä¶and I volunteered from the time I was in third grade. So, wow, it is near and dear to my heart, and I think it‚Äôs near and dear to our entire community,‚Äù she said. During that time, she‚Äôs worked to make sure the library and its programs are open to all, and is always open to suggestions and feedback from the community. ‚ÄúThe library is for everyone in our community, regardless of any factors. We don‚Äôt care about age, demographics, nothing matters: we‚Äôre all welcome at that library,‚Äù Blackledge said. ‚ÄúAnd that is really a blessing in our community, to have a place where everyone feels valued and welcome. And we‚Äôre glad that we can provide that spot. The library will be in good hands, don‚Äôt worry.‚Äù

author: /author/ians/
title: 40 per cent of Mongolia's territory faces high risk of experiencing harsh winter
text:
40 per cent of Mongolia's territory faces high risk of experiencing harsh winter
By [IANS](/author/ians/) | Published: January 3, 2025 05:43 PM2025-01-03T17:43:15+5:302025-01-03T17:45:15+5:30
Ulan Bator, Jan 3 At least 40 per cent of Mongolia's territory is now at high risk of ...
Ulan Bator, Jan 3 At least 40 per cent of Mongolia's territory is now at high risk of experiencing the extreme wintry weather 'dzud' this winter, the country's National Agency for Meteorology and Environmental Monitoring said Friday.
The dzud is a Mongolian term to describe a severely cold winter when many livestock die because the ground is frozen or covered in snow.
"A recent risk assessment of the dzud indicates that at least 40 per cent of the country's total territory faces a high risk of dzud this winter, while 20 per cent is categorized as medium risk," the weather monitoring agency said in a statement.
Most areas in the five western provinces, Bayan-Ulgii, Uvs, Khovd, Zavkhan, and Gobi-Altai, are at high or very high risk, the agency warned, Xinhua news agency reported.
Additionally, some parts of the northern provinces, Khuvsgul, Selenge, and Bulgan, the central provinces of Arkhangai and Uvurkhangai, and smaller areas of the southern provinces of Bayankhongor and Dundgovi are also at high risk.
The agency urged local authorities and nomadic herders to prepare for potential challenges to mitigate the impacts of the harsh winter conditions.
Mongolia, one of the world's last remaining nomadic nations, is known for its extreme winters, largely shaped by the Siberian high-pressure system.
Last winter, the Asian country experienced its heaviest snowfall in five decades, leading to a severe dzud that resulted in the loss of millions of livestock.
On December 23, Mongolia's National Emergency Management Agency (NEMA) had issued a severe weather warning for several regions, predicting strong winds and blizzards.
The blizzards were expected to impact the western, central, and southern Gobi provinces, resulting in poor road visibility and slippery conditions. The NEMA had urged citizens, especially nomadic herders and drivers, to exercise caution and take preventive measures against potential disasters.
The combination of frigid temperatures and unpredictable weather patterns often leads to devastating consequences for both human and animal populations, Xinhua news agency reported.
In a tragic example of such risks, over 10 people, mainly nomadic herders, lost their lives in November 2023 due to heavy snow and blizzards in the central province of Tuv and the eastern province of Sukhbaatar.
Last winter, nearly all 21 provinces of the country endured extreme wintry conditions, accompanied by record snowfall, the largest since 1975. Around 90 per cent of the country's territory was covered in snow up to 100 centimetres thick, leading to the death of approximately 8 million livestock.
Disclaimer: This post has been auto-published from an agency feed without any modifications to the text and has not been reviewed by an editor

text:
Gros coup dur pour l'√©quipe de basket belge : sa meneuse Julie Allemand (1,73 m, 28 ans), √©l√©ment phare de la conqu√™te europ√©enne des Belgian Cats en 2023, ne disputera pas les Jeux Olympiques de Paris en raison d'une blessure musculaire contract√©e √† l'entra√Ænement. La nouvelle intervient quatre jours avant l'entr√©e en lice des Belges, lundi 29 contre l'Allemagne (13h30).
L'√âQUIPE L'ancienne meneuse de l'Asvel √©tait tout juste remise d'une op√©ration √† la cheville survenue fin mars, alors qu'elle jouait encore en France, avant de rejoindre l'effectif des Los Angeles Sparks en WNBA. Le Comit√© olympique et interf√©d√©ral belge a officialis√© la nouvelle dans un communiqu√©. La joueuse, elle, a seulement r√©agi par un coeur bris√© sur son compte X, preuve de l'immense d√©ception que repr√©sente son forfait.

author: LW
title: Prince Harry's emotional mission: mend things with King Charles and family amidst cancer diagnosis | Marca
text: Prince Harry is reportedly prioritizing a visit to his father, King Charles, upon his return to England in May. The Duke of Sussex is keen on repairing their bond, especially since King Charles was diagnosed with cancer earlier this year. A source revealed to The Mirror, "Harry's first priority when he comes to England is to see his sick dad. He is pretty focused on this. It will be his first port of call when he comes off the plane to try and spend as much time with King Charles so that they can build bridges, and enjoy each other's company like before." The source further emphasized Harry's determination to make the most of his time with his family during his visit, stating, "He wants the family to get back to the way they were and is going to be making extra effort with his brother Wills too, as difficult as it may be. Now, more than ever, with Kate's cancer diagnosis too, Harry wants them to know he is there for them." Prince Harry talks seeing King Charles amid cancer battle Additionally, it was mentioned that Harry will be juggling his schedule around his charity work for the Invictus Games to ensure he can spend as much time as possible with his father. The source highlighted, "Harry knows it will be awkward, but it's a time to put pride and differences to one side. He is coming over for his charity work, which is so important to him so he will juggle his schedule accordingly, but seeing his dad will come first." During his previous visit, Harry was granted a brief 30-minute audience with his father just before King Charles commenced his cancer treatment. Despite the limited time, Harry was said to be appreciative of the opportunity to see him. Prince Harrys first priority when he comes to England next month revealed by source #PrinceHarry #RoyalFamilyhttps://t.co/u5tbUdf7lb pic.twitter.com/dfA7tQPo3G? Daily Express (@Daily_Express) April 4, 2024 Prince Harry's visit aims to revive family ties In light of recent efforts to mend strained relationships within the royal family, it was mentioned that Prince William and Princess Kate are also striving to reconcile with Prince Harry and Meghan Markle. The source indicated, "Meanwhile, Prince William and Princess Kate are trying their best to end their feud with Prince Harry and Meghan Markle." Overall, Prince Harry's upcoming visit to England holds significant importance as he aims to prioritize spending quality time with his father and rekindling familial bonds while also fulfilling his charitable commitments. Meghan Markle Is Very Anxious About Returning To England With Prince Harry In May https://t.co/mesHIA8Bmd? Womens Health (@WomensHealthMag) April 1, 2024

author: newsdirectory3
title: Samsung‚Äôs One UI 7: Beta Release Delayed for Galaxy S24 and S23, Launch Expected February
text:
Samsung is currently behind its competitors in rolling out Android 15 updates. It has not yet released the first beta version of One UI 7 , in contrast to its previous rapid update timeline.
Rumors suggest that Samsung is focused on improvements to make One UI 7 the best version yet. A leaked timeline indicates that the beta for the Galaxy S24 series will start in the first week of December. The S23 series will receive the beta 2-3 weeks later. It is uncertain whether the Galaxy S22 series will get the beta this year, and the S21 series will not participate in the beta program.
What are the main features and improvements expected in Samsung‚Äôs One UI 7 with ‚Å¢the Android 15 update? Interview ‚Äåwith a‚Å¢ Mobile ‚ÄãSoftware Specialist on Samsung‚Äôs‚Äã One UI 7 and ‚Å¢Android 15 Updates
Interviewer : Thank you for joining us‚Å¢ today.‚Äç There‚Äôs been considerable talk about ‚ÄåSamsung being behind its‚Å§ competitors in rolling out Android‚Äç 15 updates. Can you provide some‚Äã context on this delay and what might be contributing factors?
Specialist : Absolutely, it‚Äôs ‚Äçan interesting topic. Samsung‚Äôs ‚Äãupdate strategy has been a strong suite‚Å¢ of its brand‚Å¢ identity. ‚Å¢However, it seems like they are temporarily lagging, particularly ‚Äåwith the beta release of One ‚ÄãUI 7. ‚Å§Traditionally,‚Å£ Samsung has been quick to ‚Äçadopt‚Å£ the latest‚Äã Android versions, but this time they appear focused on ensuring‚Äå that One UI 7‚Äã brings significant improvements‚Å§ and‚Å§ refinements.
Interviewer : There‚Äôs speculation that they want to ‚Å§make One UI 7 the best version yet. What could ‚Äåthese improvements entail?
Specialist : From what ‚Å§we‚Äôre hearing, Samsung might be enhancing‚Å§ user interface ‚Äãelements for better accessibility and responsiveness, integrating more advanced features, and‚Äå optimizing battery performance. They might ‚Äãalso be placing a stronger emphasis on ‚Äåsecurity and privacy, which are‚Äå increasingly critical ‚Äçfeatures for users‚Äç today.
Interviewer : A leaked timeline suggests that‚Äã the beta for the Galaxy S24 series is‚Å¢ expected ‚Äãto start in the first week of December. How does ‚Å§this timeline affect the rollout ‚Å§for earlier models like the S23 ‚Å¢and S22?
Specialist : That‚Äôs ‚Äãcorrect. The Galaxy S24 series beta launch sets a crucial precedent.‚Å§ The ‚Å¢S23 series following a few weeks later is ‚Å§typical,‚Äã as those‚Å¢ models are ‚Å£still relatively new. However, the uncertainty around whether the Galaxy S22 will get included this year suggests a shift in focus ‚Äãtowards newer‚Å£ models, which could disappoint some users of the S22 series. As for the ‚Å§S21 series, it‚Äç appears they‚Å§ will miss out on this ‚Å¢beta‚Äç altogether, which might signal a transition towards prioritizing newer devices in their update‚Å£ strategy.
Interviewer : Given this approach, when can users expect a stable‚Å£ release of One‚Å¢ UI‚Å§ 7?
Specialist : If we follow the leaked ‚Å§timeline, a stable ‚Å§version should be‚Äç expected around February, following a typical beta testing period of about‚Å¢ two‚Äç months.‚Äå They plan to launch One UI 7 on the ‚ÄãGalaxy S25 series first, which emphasizes their intention ‚Å£to highlight their‚Äã latest technology through new‚Äç devices.
Interviewer : are ‚Äãusers with previous Galaxy models to be concerned about their devices‚Äô‚Å§ update futures?
Specialist : It‚Äôs always hard to gauge precisely, but this strategy might point to a more segmented focus on newer devices. Users ‚Å¢of older models may increasingly find themselves outside the immediate ‚Å£update cycle. However, Samsung‚Å¢ often reassesses its strategies, so while current plans seem‚Å¢ to ‚Äãfavor the S24 and S25, there may‚Å§ still be avenues for older models to receive‚Å¢ significant updates down the line.
The beta program is expected to last about two months, with a stable release anticipated in February. This release will occur after the launch of the Galaxy S25 series. Samsung has confirmed that One UI 7 will debut on the S25 family before being available on other devices.

author: Stocktwits Inc
title: Apple Bear Holds 'Muted' View On December Quarter Amid Regulatory Headwinds, Lukewarm iPhone Sales: Retail Sentiment Sours- Asianet News English
text:
Apple Bear Holds ‚ÄòMuted‚Äô View On December Quarter Amid Regulatory Headwinds, Lukewarm iPhone Sales: Retail Sentiment Sours Barclays sees increased pressure on the App Store regulatory front and ‚Äòpotential noise‚Äô‚Äô around Apple‚Äôs China exposure, in terms of sales and supply chain, in the wake of the changing political backdrop.
Stocktwits Inc First Published Jan 10, 2025, 11:01 AM IST | Last Updated Jan 10, 2025, 11:01 AM IST Follow Apple, Inc. ($AAPL) is scheduled to report its fiscal year first quarter results after the market closes on Thursday, Jan. 30, and an analyst said he expects a mixed performance from the tech giant.
Barclays analysts maintained an ‚ÄòUnderweight‚Äô rating and $184 price target for Apple stock, suggesting nearly 25% downside from current levels.
The stock had a strong run in 2024, rallying 31% in 2024 versus S&P 500‚Äôs 23% gain. It hit an all-time high of $260.10 on Dec. 24.
Commenting on the 2024 stock move, the analysts said much of the performance was driven by multiple expansion despite a weaker-than-expected iPhone and increased regulatory risks.
Apple‚Äôs App Store business has been under pressure from regulators and developers in recent years. Last year, the company was forced to revamp its operations to conform with new European Union (EU) laws. It also changed its commission structure in the EU and opened up its devices to third-party marketplaces.
The company is also in the crosshairs of a U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) probe for monopolizing the smartphone market.
Barclays said it expects Apple to start 2025 with a ‚Äúmixed, at best‚Äù earnings release for the all-important December quarter, which encompasses the key holiday selling season.
On average, analysts expect Apple to report first-quarter earnings per share of $2.35, up from $2.18 a year ago, and revenue of $124.77 billion versus $119.58 reported last year.
Barclays models some recovery in iPhone sales as the installed base ages but the firm calls for choppiness through 2025.
The firm said it looks forward to getting more clarity on the Google traffic acquisition cost TAC), which Alphabet pays to Apple for keeping its search as the default search engine on all iOS devices. U.S. regulators have raised red flag over this relationship as they question Google‚Äôs search monopoly.
AAPL sentiment and message volume January 9, 2025, as of 10:59 pm ET | Source: Stocktwits On Stocktwits, retail sentiment toward Apple stock reversed to ‚Äòbearish‚Äô (44/100) from ‚Äòbullish‚Äô a day ago, with message volume shrinking to ‚Äòlow.‚Äô
An Apple watcher on the platform flagged the possibility of the stock pulling back to the $217-$229 area before buying kicks in.
The stock settled Wednesday‚Äôs session down 0.20% at $242.70. It has lost over 3% since the start of the new year.
For updates and corrections, email newsroom[at]stocktwits[dot]com.<
